user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 1.2 is: Language extensions should not be used.
You should report only when the code uses any language compiler extensions that are explicitly stated as an extension in compiler documentations.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64:
```c
_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64 (uint64_t size,
                                         int fd,
                                         uint64_t offset)
{
  struct MHD_Response *response;

#if ! defined(HAVE___LSEEKI64) && ! defined(HAVE_LSEEK64)
  if ( (sizeof(uint64_t) > sizeof(off_t)) &&
       ( (size > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         (offset > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         ((size + offset) >= (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ) )
    return NULL;
#endif
  if ( ((int64_t) size < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) offset < 0) ||
       ((int64_t) (size + offset) < 0) )
    return NULL;

  response = MHD_create_response_from_callback (size,
                                                MHD_FILE_READ_BLOCK_SIZE,
                                                &file_reader,
                                                NULL,
                                                &free_callback);
  if (NULL == response)
    return NULL;
  response->fd = fd;
  response->is_pipe = false;
  response->fd_off = offset;
  response->crc_cls = response;
  return response;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
suspicious_frags:
#if ! defined(HAVE___LSEEKI64) && ! defined(HAVE_LSEEK64)
  if ( (sizeof(uint64_t) > sizeof(off_t)) &&
       ( (size > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         (offset > (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ||
         ((size + offset) >= (uint64_t) INT32_MAX) ) )
    return NULL;
#endif

_MHD_EXTERN struct MHD_Response *
MHD_create_response_from_fd_at_offset64 (uint64_t size,
                                         int fd,
                                         uint64_t offset)
explanation: I did not mark any other fragments because the remaining code uses standard C features: fixed-width integer types (uint64_t, int64_t), standard casts and comparisons, NULL, standard macros like INT32_MAX, standard boolean literal (false), ordinary function calls and assignments, and struct pointer operations. There are no obvious GCC/MSVC __attribute__ or __declspec uses, inline assembler, nonstandard keywords, or other compiler-specific syntax elsewhere in the snippet. The three reported fragments warrant investigation because they reference macros/identifiers that commonly expand to or indicate platform/compiler-specific extensions (symbol-visibility/linkage macros and platform-specific 64-bit file-offset support and POSIX-type usage).
